subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Question, How to get the U sound in "Up"?
msgSnippet: Ed Gaddy wrote: I am so very impressed with Quickscript that I am quite willing to accept it as is. It is practically completely phonetic, very compact,
messageBody:
Ed Gaddy wrote:
I am so very impressed with Quickscript that I am quite willing to accept it as is. It is practically completely phonetic, very compact, without diacrits, quick to go on paper, and, I think, attractive. Read really did a fine job!

I agree with you Ed.  As an example of QS's utility, I attended a meeting of a non-profit corporation I am a member of over the weekend.  Inadvertently, I have become the defacto secretary because I can take notes quickly.  I took three pages of notes in QS and then later transcribed them onto my laptop in roman.

Thus, it is evident that although QS was not intended to function as a true shorthand, it is so much more efficient than using roman to write English that it can serve as an acceptable substitute for a shorthand.  It was certainly easier getting an accurate record of the meeting using QS than it would have been using roman.  Obviously, this would be a useful skill for students taking notes in class to have at their fingertips, so to speak.  I believe we should try to stress these sorts of uses for QS to get people thinking about how they can use QS in their lives.

Paige
